`PyFixest` is a Python package for fast high-dimensional fixed effects regression.

The package aims to mimic the syntax and functionality of [Laurent Berg√©'s](https://sites.google.com/site/laurentrberge/) formidable [fixest](https://github.com/lrberge/fixest) package as closely as Python allows: if you know `fixest` well, the goal is that you won't have to read the docs to get started! In particular, this means that all of `fixest's` defaults are mirrored by `PyFixest`.

## Installation

You can install `pyfixest` from [PyPi](https://pypi.org/project/pyfixest/) https://pypi.org/project/pyfixest/ via 

```bash
pip install -U pyfixest
```

## A First Regression

In a first step, we load an example data set: 

```{python}
import pyfixest as pf

data = pf.get_data()
data.head()
```

`PyFixest`'s core estimation function is called `feols()`. As a bare minimum, you need to pass a `pandas` or `polars` data frame 
and a Wilkinson formula.  

In the example below, `Y` denotes the dependent variable, `X1` a covariate, and `f1` and `f2` are fixed effects. 

```{python}
fit = pf.feols("Y ~ X1 | f1 + f2", data=data)
fit.summary()
```

We can also obtain the regression results as a `tidy` data frame: 

```{python}
fit.tidy()
```

And we can visualise the regression results via a plotting method. 

```{python}
fit.coefplot()
```

## Other relevant Features

**Multiple estimation** - via specialised syntax, it is possible to fit multiple models at once. 
For details, see [Multiple Estimation](tutorials/multiple-estimation.qmd).

```{python}
multi_fit = pf.feols("Y ~ X1 | csw0(f1, f2)", data=data)
multi_fit.etable()
```

**Instrumental variables** - `PyFixest` wouldn't be a full regression package with support for instrumental variables estimation. 
For details, take a look at the [Instrumental Variables](tutorials/instrumental-variables.qmd) vignette. 

```{python}
pf.feols("Y ~ 1 | f1 | X1 ~ Z1", data=data).summary()
```

**Poisson regression** for count data:

You can also fit Poisson regressions with fixed effects via the `fepois` function, and GLMs with fixed effects via `feglm`. 

```{python}
pois_data = pf.get_data(model="Fepois")
pf.fepois("Y ~ X1 | f1 + f2", data=pois_data).summary()
```

For details, see [here](tutorials/poisson-glm.qmd). 

**Cluster-robust standard errors** --- adjust inference on-the-fly:

`PyFixest` supports a wide range of standard errors - iid, heteroskedastic, cluster robust, as well as resampling based methods. 

```{python}
fit.vcov({"CRV1": "group_id"}).summary()
```

**Quantile regression**:

Last, `PyFixest` offers support for fast [Quantile Regression](tutorials/quantile-regression.qmd): 

```{python}
pf.quantreg("Y ~ X1 + X2", data=data, quantile=0.5).summary()
```
